stem: A client with a large pericardial effusion is being monitored. Based on the documentation in the Hemodynamic & Cardiac Sound Log, which finding indicates the development of cardiac tamponade?

options.text: The progressive narrowing of the pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic)
The increase in systolic blood pressure

rationale.correct: The correct answer is **The progressive narrowing of the pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic) (a1)**. While muffled heart sounds and JVD are part of Beck's Triad, the narrowing pulse pressure is one of the most critical and earliest hemodynamic shifts. As fluid fills the pericardium, it 'crushes' the heart, preventing the ventricles from filling (reducing SBP) and increasing the base pressure (maintaining DBP). This brings the two numbers closer and closer (104/86 -> 82/78). If the pulse pressure becomes zero, the heart cannot pump at all.
clinicalPearls: Beck's Triad: Big neck veins (JVD), Bad Blood Pressure (Low/Narrow), Buried Heart Sounds (Muffled).
Narrow Pulse Pressure = The heart is being 'squeezed' from the outside.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing JVD or muffled sounds because they are 'on the list.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While all are correct in Beck's Triad, the **trend of pulse pressure** is the most precise indicator of the *progression* of the tamponade in a 'Chart/Exhibit' style item.

mnemonic.title: Squeeze-Play
mnemonic.expansion: Fluid in the sac. Heart can't beat back. Pressure gets tight. Tamponade is in sight.

exhibits.title: Cardiac Auscultation
exhibits.content: Current: Heart sounds are noted to be 'heard as if from a great distance' and are rhythmically muffled. No murmurs or gallops noted.

exhibits.title: Neck & Peripheral Exam
exhibits.content: Neck: Jugular vein distention (JVD) noted even when the client is sitting up at 45 degrees. Lungs: Clear in all fields.
